Hail thou, whose muse contemning grandeur's bowers,</br>Erewhile in native dignity arrayed</br>An artless "shepherd-boy's" unfolding powers,</br>And bright, romantick reveries displayed</br>In strains, which fell oblivion's envious shade,</br>Secure in genuine grace, can never fear,</br>While sphere-born harmony's delicious aid,</br>While chaste simplicity's enchanting air,</br>And fancy's vivid hues the poet's toils endear.

O, though so favoured of the partial Nine,</br>Though fond, with plausive breath, thy name to raise,</br>Taste, beauty, genius, piety combine;</br>Accept the thanks a youthful rustick pays,</br>Whom yet the beauties of thy polished lays</br>With mingled sorrow, deep regret inspire,</br>(Though much he could thy recent labours praise,)</br>That silent sleeps so long that nobler fire,</br>And all neglected lies thy more illustrious lyre.

The landscape bright, the thought with justness new,</br>Pourtrayed in prose, can interest the heart;</br>Yet (though unchanged the thought, unchanged the view)</br>A more consummate pleasure they impart,</br>Embellished by the sweet, Phoebean art;</br>When poesy exults, or tender grieves,</br>Much more of joy we feel or pitying smart,</br>While memory on her most retentive leaves,</br>Smit with the charms of sound the dulcet notes receives.

But ah!  how few of genius' honoured train</br>Possess with strength of mind poetick skill!</br>And even, of those, how oft the insidious strain</br>Infuses grovelling thoughts and passions ill!</br>O suasive, elegant, sublime at will,</br>Whose flowery page ne'er sheltered aught impure,</br>Employ thy talents yet again to instill</br>The liberal wish; from lust of gain secure:</br>And to fair virtue's path the wavering heart allure.

Yet, yet sweet bard, resume thy Edwin's tale,</br>When manhood's dangerous eminence he gained:</br>O say what touching incidents befel,</br>What rural maid his gentle bosom pained,</br>And, with sweet artlessness, his heart enchained.</br>"Ye cherub train" that brought him on his way,</br>As yet with pride and black distrust unstained,</br>O leave him not "'midst tumult and dismay,"</br>Warm love, and thankful hope, and calm contentment, stay.

These simple rhymes shall unlamented die,</br>And quickly vanish in oblivion due;</br>Yet shouldst thou chance, with condescending eye,</br>The fond request therein preferred to view,</br>And, thence aroused, that pleasing theme pursue,</br>Then to the bare request, however penned,</br>Of praise, some slender portion might accrue;</br>Then might my name avowed to fame pretend,</br>And gentle souls unborn the weak attempt commend.</br>
